metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Deoman Upadhyaya

facts.text: Deoman was married to Dulari whose parents died in infancy and who was brought up by Sukhdei, her aunt.
Sukhdei gifted certain agricultural lands inherited from her father to Dulari.
Lands gifted to Dulari and Sukhdei's lands were cultivated by Mahabir, uncle of Deoman.
Mahabir and Deoman entered negotiations for sale of some lands at village Anandadih, but Sukhdei refused to agree.
In the evening of June 18, 1958, altercation between Deoman and Sukhdei over proposed sale; Deoman slapped Sukhdei and threatened to smash her face.
Early morning June 19, 1958, Deoman assaulted Sukhdei with gandasa borrowed from Mahesh while she slept in courtyard, killed her, threw gandasa into village tank, washed himself, absconded.
Deoman arrested afternoon of June 20, 1958 near village Manapur.
On June 21, 1958, Deoman offered to hand over gandasa thrown in tank; in presence of investigating officer and witnesses, waded into tank and recovered gandasa stained with human blood.
Before day-break June 19, 1958, Deoman seen hurrying towards tank by witness, then bathing in tank.
Deoman absconded immediately after and not found in Anandadih on June 19, 1958.
Civil Sessions Judge Gyanpur convicted Deoman of murder, sentenced to death subject to confirmation.
High Court set aside conviction and sentence, acquitted Deoman.
High Court Division Bench referred questions on validity of S.27 Evidence Act and S.162(2) CrPC to Full Bench.
Full Bench: Mukherjee J and Srivastava J held S.27 void under Art.14; Desai J dissented.
High Court excluded Deoman's statement under S.27, found evidence insufficient, acquitted.
High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court on constitutional validity of S.27.
Story of borrowing gandasa from Mahesh on June 18 evening unreliable (High Court view).
Dead body of Sukhdei found morning June 19, 1958 with incised injuries by gandasa.

legal_issues.text: Whether S.27 of the Indian Evidence Act is void as offending Art.14 of the Constitution?
Whether sub-s.(2) of S.162 of the Code of Criminal Procedure insofar as it relates to S.27 Evidence Act is void?
Whether Deoman committed murder of Sukhdei?

petitioner_arguments.text: S.27 Evidence Act does not violate Art.14; no unjustifiable discrimination between persons in custody and not in custody; persons in custody need greater protection; theoretical possibility of non-custody statements does not invalidate.
Evidence including recovery of blood-stained gandasa at Deoman's instance, altercation, threat, absconding proves guilt beyond doubt.

respondent_arguments.text: S.27 Evidence Act creates unjustifiable discrimination between accused in custody and not in custody, violating Art.14; same evidence could convict one and acquit another based on custody status.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art.14 Constitution; S.27 Evidence Act; S.162 CrPC

respondent_arguments.text: Deoman not accused of offence at time of statement; evidence insufficient without S.27 statement.

court_reasoning.text: S.27 is proviso allowing proof of information from accused in police custody leading to discovery of fact; distinction between custody and non-custody not arbitrary as custody persons need more protection; practical problems justify; no real class of non-custody voluntary disclosures without surrender.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature free to recognize degrees of harm; S.27 hits evil where most felt.

court_reasoning.text: S.162(2) CrPC exception for S.27 valid; expression 'accused of any offence' descriptive, not requiring formal charge.

Circumstantial evidence: altercation and threat, seen near tank post-murder, absconding, recovery of blood-stained gandasa at instance form complete chain proving Deoman murdered Sukhdei with gandasa.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even without borrowing evidence, chain consistent only with guilt.

court_reasoning.text: Offence brutal, premeditated on defenceless woman; death sentence appropriate.

holdings.text: S.27 Indian Evidence Act and S.162(2) CrPC not void under Art.14.
Deoman guilty of murder under S.302 IPC; conviction and death sentence restored and confirmed.

precedents_cited.relevance: S.25 covers confession to police before investigation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Legal Remembrancer v. Lalit Mohan Singh
precedents_cited.relevance: Person giving information to police deemed in custody.
Submission to custody by word or action.
Information leading to discovery by non-custody person.

precedents_cited.case_name: West Coast Hotel Company v. Parrish
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature not bound to extend to all cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: Basheshar Nath v. Commissioner of Income-tax

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of confessions and information leading to discovery; S.27 held valid.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Custody, statements to police; S.162(2) exception for S.27 valid.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Equal protection; no violation by S.27.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the State's appeal, set aside High Court acquittal, restored Sessions Court conviction for murder and death sentence, confirmed the sentence under Art.136.
outcome.relief_granted: Conviction under S.302 IPC restored; death sentence confirmed.

key_quotes.text: "Section 27 is founded on the principle that even though the evidence relating to confessional or other statements made by a person, whilst he is in the custody of a police officer, is tainted and therefore inadmissible, if the truth of the information given by him is assured by the discovery of a fact, it may be presumed to be untainted."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The evidence that Deoman had in the presence of the witnesses offered to point out the gandasa which he said he had thrown into tank was accepted by the Trial Court and the High Court has not disagreed."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The quarrel between Deoman and Sukhdei and the threat uttered by him that he would smash Sukhdei's mouth/face and his absconding immediately after the death of Sukhdei by violence, lend very strong support to the case for the prosecution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
